Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 06:51PM gemsa wrote: 31andscared, Please get a second opinion, if only for your peace of mind. Also, you can find a lot of information about young women and breast cancer at www.youngsurvival.org. There is a great group of women there as well that know what you are going through. I chose a bilateral mastectomy as well, because like you said, we have long lived ahead of us and don't want to have to deal with this again. It also helps with the symmetry. Good luck! Tina

Posts.Content: May 16, 2007 01:59PM gemsa wrote: I had a lump ultrsound as well, and they said it was dilated ducts. It was cancer. I was 28. See if you can get a fine needle biopsy of the lump from a breast specialits or breast surgeon. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 12:13AM gemsa wrote: Everything you are feeling is completely normal! Try to breathe, take a walk, do some yoga. Talk to your doctor about anything you don't understand and ask questions until you get it. If your husband is still on his trip, be sure to bring someone with you to appointments, not only for support, but to take notes for you. You can get through this!

Posts.Title: Dx is in Pat634 gemsa

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 11:02AM gemsa wrote: Dear Patrice, I had neoadjuvant chemo (chemo before surgery) too. Do you know what kind you are getting? I had adriamycin and taxotere and never had mouth sores. With the new drugs they have, they can prevent a lot of the nausea and vomiting that was characteristic of chemo years ago. Stay strong, and keep coming to this group for support! Tina
Posts.Title: Dx is in Pat634 gemsa

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 07:32PM gemsa wrote: Hanaki, I had discharge out of one side too, and my doctors said it was breast milk, even though I had never been pregnant. They tested my pituitary too, which ended up being normal. I had a breast lump too, which they said was a cyst. It ended up being cancer. You have a very strong family history - they should be taking you much more seriously. The can do a cytologic exam of the discharge to test for cancer cells. You should ask for more testing. Stick with it until they give you a definitive diagnosis for what is wrong. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Am I overreacting? Not sure what to do now. : ( Hanaki gemsa

Posts.Content: gemsa wrote: Living with Lymphedema and Other Chronic Swelling Issues Two ladies from the Young Survival Coalition Chicago Affiliate, Pam and Jen, will participate on a panel discussion at this event, presented by Stay Fit Physical Therapy and Core Wellness. Program highlights include an overview of the lymphatic system, a panel discussion including experts and patients, differences between lymphedema and other chronic swelling issues, physical therapy, exercise considerations, and pressure garment considerations. This program will take place on Wednesday, July 15, 2009 at Stay Fit Physical Therapy, 127 W. Prospect Avenue, Mount Prospect, IL. Call to Register: (847) 255-2348 My story: www.tinakoral.com Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Free lymphedema discussion with experts, Chicago area gemsa gemsa

Posts.Content: gemsa wrote: Good afternoonÂ breastcancer.org members! We're happy to announce the initiation of the Young Survival Coalition (YSC) Chicagoland Community Volunteer Groups (CVGs)! CVGs represent the YSC as volunteers in a local community and are organized solely to support the YSC mission. We will serve as a point of contact for young women affected by breast cancer by coordinating informal networking opportunities and raising awareness in our communities by distributing YSC materials to local hospitals and breast cancer organizations. If you are a young breast cancer survivor who wishes to be in touch with other survivors in your area, please use the links below to contact the CVG leader: DuPage County: yscdupage@yahoo.com Kankakee County: ysckankakeeco@yahoo.com McHenry County: ysc_mchenrycty@yahoo.com Will County: yscwillco@yahoo.com We look forward to furthering the YSC's mission in Chicagoland! For more information on the YSC, visit www.youngsurvival.org. My story: www.tinakoral.com Log in to post a reply
